input: Answer this question about Italy: 1.1 What body/agency grants banking licenses? Please include the name of licensing agency. If more than one, please describe their respective licensing roles.
target: Within the SSM, the European Central Bank (ECB) is the competent authority for granting a bank license. Pursuant to article 14 of the Council Regulation (EU) No 1024/2013 of 15 October 2013 conferring specific tasks on the European Central Bank concerning policies relating to the prudential supervision of credit institutions (â€œSSM Regulation), Any application for an authorisation to banking business of a credit institution to be established in a SSM Member State must be submitted to the national competent authorities (NCAs) of the Member State where the credit institution is to be established in accordance with the requirements set out in relevant national law. If the applicant complies with all conditions of authorisation set out in the relevant national law of that Member State, the NCA takes, within the period provided for by relevant national law, a draft decision to propose to the ECB to grant the authorisation. In other cases, the national competent authority shall reject the application for authorisation. The NCA draft decision is adopted by the ECB unless the ECB objects within a maximum period of ten working days (extendable once for the same period in duly justified cases). The ECB can object to the draft decision only where the conditions for authorisation set out in relevant Union law are not met.

input: Answer this question about United Kingdom: 1.1 What body/agency grants banking licenses? Please include the name of licensing agency. If more than one, please describe their respective licensing roles.
target:
The PRA performs the role of authorising a bank (and therefore granting a banking license). Section 55A (2) of Financial Services & Markets Act (â€˜FSMAâ€™) stipulates that an application is made to the PRA if the regulated activities to which the application relates consist of or include a PRA-regulated activity. The authorisation of a bank is dependent on that entity undertaking the regulated activity of deposit-taking, which is designated as a PRA regulated activity under the secondary legislation of section 2 of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (PRA-regulated Activities) Order 2013 (â€˜RAOâ€™). The PRA is required to seek the consent of the FCA before an applicant can be authorised. Once authorised, the firm will then have a Part 4A permission (granted under the powers spelt out in Part 4a of FSMA, so hence known as a â€˜Part 4a permissionâ€™) to carry on regulated activities. The assessment criteria are both regulatorsâ€™ Threshold Conditions, which consider such topics as adequate financial and non-financial resources. Underpinning these Conditions are European legislation. For banks, in particular meeting the Capital Requirements Regulations (â€˜CRRâ€™) is also important. _x000D_
The exception to this is EEA banks that operate in the UK through a branch or on a cross border basis and whose home regulator is in another EEA state. Where these firms operate within the scope of their European â€œpassportâ€, they are automatically authorised under Schedule 3 to FSMA once the passporting notification procedure is completed. This process does not involve a separate decision by the PRA to grant authorization.

target: LB: HK$300 million; RLB: HK$100 million; DTC: HK$25 million. Hong Kong maintains a three-tier structure of authorized institutions: (i) LB â€“ Only LB may carry on banking business, i.e. provide current and savings accounts and demand deposits, without restriction on size or maturity, and pay or collect cheques. (ii) RLB - RLB may not carry on banking business and are restricted to taking call, notice of time deposits from the public in the amounts of HK$500,000 and above. (iii) DTC - DTC are restricted to taking deposits of HK$100,000 and above and with a maturity of at least three months.

input: Answer this question about Mexico: 1.4 What is the minimum capital entry requirement for bank operations of the following types? (in [Currency Unit] of [Currency])         Yes - Explanation
target:
According to article 19 of the Credit Institutions Law (LIC), those banks willing to undertake all the services or operations foreseen under Article 46 of the LIC, should have a minimum paid-in capital equivalent in Mexican pesos to 90 million Inflation-Indexed-Units (Udis or Unidades de InversiÃ³n), while those banks willing to perform some but not all of those services or operations should have:_x000D_
a) Fifty-four million investment units (UDIs) for banks that have set forth in their bylaws the performance of the transactions described in LIC article 46, fractions I, II, III, IV, V, VI, VII, VIII, XI, XXIII, XXIV, XXV and XXVI._x000D_
b) Thirty-six million investment units (UDIs) for banks which have chosen the following options:_x000D_
i.	Provide financial services considering some of the following operations: _x000D_
â€“	Those stipulated in article 46, fractions I, II, IV and XVI. These operations must be carried out only with qualified investors, institutional investors or legal entities._x000D_
â€“	Those stipulated in article 46, fractions V, IX, X, XI, XII, XV, XVII, XVIII, XIX, XX, XXI, XXII, XXIII and XXVII, the latter where necessary to fulfill their object._x000D_
ii.	Execute those operations related to the issuance of currency, considering specific operations established in LIC article 46.

input: Answer this question about Norway: 1.4 What is the minimum capital entry requirement for bank operations of the following types? (in [Currency Unit] of [Currency])         Yes - Explanation
target:
1.4. a. Minimum capital entry requirements are set individually. All aspects of the applicant's planned business and risk profile, e.g. concentration risk are considered. In addition, new banks are given an additional capital surcharge of 2 percentage points based on the added risk of establishing a new bank.

1.4. c. Branches of banks from the European Economic Area (comprises the EU, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Norway) are not subject to separate capital entry requirements in Norway. Minimum capital entry requirements for non-EEA branches are set individually. The capital must be deposited in Norway, and managed in a satisfactory manner by a Norwegian bank. This divide holds for most aspects of the regulatory landscape in the Norwegian banking sector.

input: Answer this question about Romania: 1.4 What is the minimum capital entry requirement for bank operations of the following types? (in [Currency Unit] of [Currency])         Yes - Explanation
target: (1) Banks, Romanian legal persons, must have at the time of authorization an initial capital of at least 37 million lei (EUR 8,063,462 using 4.5886 FX rate as of 25 of August 2017); In case of bridge-bank, the share capital may be below the level of EUR 5 million, but not be less than the RON equivalent of EUR 1 million. (2) Mortgage banks must have an initial capital of at least 25 million lei (EUR 5,448,285 using 4.5886 FX rate as of 25 of August 2017) at the time of authorization; (3) Savings and lending banks in the housing sector must have at the moment of authorization an initial capital level of at least 25 million lei; (4) The branches in Romania of credit institutions from third countries will permanently maintain the initial capital at least to the applicable minimum level established, according to points (1) to (3) as appropriate; (5) The minimum initial capital and central bank's own funds, respectively, are set at the equivalent in RON of EUR 5 million; (6) The minimum limit of a credit co-operative's own funds is set at 300 thousand lei (EUR 65,379 using 4.5886 FX rate as of 25 of August 2017); (7) The minimum level of the aggregate capital and, respectively, of the own funds of a cooperative network shall be set at the equivalent in lei of EUR 10 million.

The Superintendent will have ninety days from the time of the submittal of the complete documentation required by the Superintendency, to approve or refuse the petition for a banking license, taking the following criteria into account:_x000D_
1. Identity of the principal shareholders and professional competence of the administrative staff based on their experience, integrity, and professional background. _x000D_
2. Evidence of their capacity to contribute the required minimum capital, the origin of which must be clearly determinable. _x000D_
3. A business plan which clearly demonstrates the viability of the bank and its contribution to the Panamanian economy. _x000D_
4. Corporate governance policies. _x000D_
5. Any other criteria that the Superintendent or the Board of Directors considers pertinent. The time period referred to in this article may be extended at the discretion of the Superintendent, when he/she considers it necessary for a better evaluation of the particular petition._x000D_
_x000D_
Rule - 3-2001, ARTICLE 2. MORAL AND FINANCIAL SOLVENCY. The natural persons that apply for a banking license to the Superintendency for a foreign-formed Bank or as promoters of a new Bank in the process of being formed, as also their directors, officials and main stockholders, must possess a renowned moral and financial solvency. Therefore, the requested banking license will not be granted if any of the previously mentioned persons: _x000D_
a. Has been convicted of money laundering, illicit traffic of drugs, fraud, illegal traffic of arms or persons, kidnapping, extortion, embezzlement, corruption of public servants, acts of terrorism, international traffic of vehicles, or of any crime against property or legal authority; _x000D_
b. Is disqualified to practice commercial activities, in Panama or in another country; _x000D_
c. Has been declared bankrupt or in civil contest of creditors; _x000D_
d. Has been identified by the Superintendency as responsible in the Bank for the acts that lead to the compulsory liquidation of the Bank._x000D_

input: Answer this question about India: 2.2 What are the requirements for evaluation / approval of significant bank shareholders? 2.3.3 Please specify any differences that exist in the maximum percentage of a bank's equity owned by a single owner for domestic versus foreign owners.
target: Acquisition of shareholding in a private sector bank shall be subject to the extant Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) policy, subject to specific requirements, if any, in the respective licensing guidelines. In terms of the Government of India FDI policy (of April 2015), the aggregate foreign investment in private sector banks from all sources (Foreign Direct Investment, Foreign Institutional Investors, Non Resident Indians) shall not exceed 74 per cent of paid-up capital of the bank. At all times, at least 26 per cent of the paid-up share capital of the private sector banks shall be held by resident Indians. The foreign investment limits and sub-limits and also computation of foreign investment in the private sector banks shall be as specified in the FDI policy of the Government of India and The Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999 regulations as amended from time to time.

input: Answer this question about Armenia: 3.6 The regulatory minimum capital requirements are applied 3.9.1 Please describe these differences along with the specific risk weights that are being applied.
target:
Claims on foreign governments and central banks issued in domestic currency are assigned 0%, 20%, 50%, 100%, 150% risk weights based on rating from recognized credit rating agency (if not rated then 100% risk weight is assigned).
Claims on domestic public sector entities issued in domestic currency fall under the category â€˜otherâ€™ and are issued 100% risk weight.
Claims (both in domestic and foreign currency) on certain financial institutions and multilateral development banks are assigned a zero risk weight.
Claims on foreign banks issued in domestic currency are assigned 20%, 50%, 100%, 150% based on rating while claims on banks and foreign bank branches operating in Armenia are assigned 50% risk weight.
Mortgage loans issued in domestic currency are assigned either 35% or 75% or 100% based on criteria as specified by Regulation 2.
All Exposures with few exceptions issued in foreign currency are assigned a risk weight which is 50% higher than the risk weights assigned to exposures denominated in domestic currency.
The credit risk is calculated under the BASEL II framework. Hence, the list of exposures assigned a specific risk weight is wider than the one in BASEL I. The full list can be found in Annex 3 of Regulation 2 of Central Bank of Armenia.

input: Answer this question about Colombia: 3.6 The regulatory minimum capital requirements are applied 3.9.1 Please describe these differences along with the specific risk weights that are being applied.
target:
Weigh 20%: The regulation does differentiate if the operations are with the OECD or not. Therefore, numerals b, c, d and e of operations that weigh 20% under Basel, under our regulation, those operations are weighted with 100%. Weigh 50%: There are some differences between Basel and our regulation regarding the criteria that must be taken into account to give 50% to mortgage loans: Mortgage loan whose guarantee is the same house and that hasn’t been restructured. However restructured with a credit rating of A or B will be weighted in this category. Off balance sheet items: There are some differences between Basel and our regulation regarding for these operations. The operations and weight can be found in page of the following link.
https://www.superfinanciera.gov.co/descargas?com=institucional&name=pubFile1011354&downloadname=cap13_14patrimoniotecnicorelacionesminsolvencia.docx 
Other weighs: Investments made in securities deriving from securitization processes will have a weighting differentiated by the risk rating granted by a rating agency. In this sense, the weight could be between 20% and 300%. Transactions with territorial entities will be weighted differently by the risk rating granted by a rating agency. In this sense, the weight could be between 90% and a limit of 130%.

input: Answer this question about Costa Rica: 3.6 The regulatory minimum capital requirements are applied 3.9.1 Please describe these differences along with the specific risk weights that are being applied.
target:
Se aplica un requerimiento mínimo global de capital de 10%. Diferencias para riesgo de crédito: 0%: Efectivo, activos y pasivos contingentes de bancos multilaterales, activos y pasivos contingentes de emisores y deudores calificados en categoría de riesgo 0, Avales, garantías y cartas de crédito de importación y exportación con depósito previo por monto cubierto y líneas de crédito de tarjeta de crédito. 10%: Back to back, activos y pasivos contingentes de emisores y deudores calificados en categoría de riesgo 1, activos y pasivos contingentes denominados en moneda extranjera en el BCCR y Gobierno de la República de Costa Rica. 25%: Activos y pasivos contingentes de emisores y deudores calificados en categoría de riesgo 2 50%: Activos y pasivos contingentes de emisores y deudores calificados en categoría de riesgo 3, créditos hipotecarios residenciales para personas físicas aplica la siguiente tabla de ponderación: 
Generadores LTV<40%: 25.00%, 40%≤LTV<60%:30.00%, 60%≤LTV<80%: 40.00%, 80%≤LTV<90%: 50.00%,90%≤LTV<100%: 60.00%, LTV≥100%: 80.00%.
No Generadores: LTV<40%: 31.25%, 40%≤LTV<60%: 37.50%, 60%≤LTV<80%: 50.00%, 80%≤LTV<90%: 62.50%, 90%≤LTV<100%:75.00%, LTV≥100%:100.00%. 
75%: Activos más pasivos contingentes de emisores y deudores con calificación pública en categoría de riesgo 4, inversiones en operaciones de recompra (valores con pacto de reventa. 90%: Activos más pasivos contingentes de emisores y deudores con calificación pública en categoría de riesgo 100%: Activos más pasivos contingentes, productos y cuentas por cobrar no incluidos en ponderaciones anteriores. Las operaciones con deudores expuestos a riesgos cambiarios de crédito ponderan al 125%. Diferencias para riesgo de precio: Se aplica a la cartera de inversiones en valores una metodología de “Valor en Riesgo (VeR)”, multiplicado por un factor de corrección de seis. Diferencias para riesgo operacional: Se aplica el 15% de la utilidad operacional bruta ajustada promedio anual de los últimos 36 meses Diferencias para riesgo cambiario: Se multiplica el valor absoluto de la posición neta total en divisas por un factor de riesgo del 10%. Diferencias para riesgo de precio de liquidación en derivados cambiarios: a. La exposición por riesgo de
precio de liquidación deberá calcularse para cada cliente o contraparte, según la siguiente fórmula: APRC = [Valor razonable – Mitigador] x Ponderador de Riesgo Donde: APRC = Activo ponderado para cada cliente o contraparte por riesgo de precio de liquidación Diferencias para riesgo de tasas de interés a.
Para cada tramo de vencimiento existe un ponderador que determina la sensibilidad de las posiciones al riesgo de variación en las tasas de interés, según el siguiente cuadro: 1 mes o menos, Ponderador de riesgo(posición en moneda extranjera)0,00%, Ponderador de riesgo (posición en moneda nacional); 1 a 3 meses, Ponderador de riesgo(posición en moneda extranjera)0,20%, Ponderador de riesgo(posición en moneda nacional)0,62%; 3 a 6 meses, Ponderador de riesgo(posición en moneda extranjera)0,40%, Ponderador de riesgo(posición en moneda nacional)1,12%; 6 a 12 meses, Ponderador de riesgo(posición en moneda extranjera)0,70%, Ponderador de riesgo(posición en moneda nacional)2,22%; Más de 12 meses, Ponderador de riesgo(posición en moneda extranjera)1,25%, Ponderador de riesgo(posición en moneda nacional)3.87%.

input: Answer this question about Panama: 3.6 The regulatory minimum capital requirements are applied 3.9.1 Please describe these differences along with the specific risk weights that are being applied.
target:
'-It redefines the concept of regulatory capital going from Tier 1 and Tier 2 to Tier 1 Capital (composed of common tier one capital + additional tier one capital) and Tier 2 Capital.
-Risk-weighted assets changed from 5 categories (from 0% to 100% weighting) to 10 categories (from 0% to 250% weighting).
-New ratios are set for common tier one capital which may not be less than 4.5% of risk-weighted assets and tier one capital may not be less than 6% of the risk-weighted assets.
-There is more precision with capital deductions
-A leverage ratio is included where common tier one capital must not be less than 3% of unweighted risk assets on and off-balance sheet.

125% to the consumer portfolio (cars) and 150% to personal loans of more than 5 years.

input: Answer this question about Luxembourg: 3.19 Which of the following are legally allowed in regulatory capital and which are the minimum (or maximum) percentages? Enter Yes or No. If the response is Yes, include corresponding minimum (or maximum) percentages (e.g. 50 means 50%) for each option that apply below. If the response is No, please explain its treatment.         Explanation
target: Legal requirements are defined as a minimum: Minimum CET1 = 4.5%, no cap on CET 1; Minimum Tier 1 = 4.5% CET1 + 1.5% AT1 = 6%, no cap on Tier 1. Minimum Total Capital Ratio = 4.5% CET 1 + 1.5% AT 1 + 2% Tier 2 = 8%. The prudential ratios outlined above represent the minimum legal requirements that are defined by quality of capital instrument. There is no minimum requirement for Tier 2. The CRR allows institutions to use capital instruments of a higher quality (rather than of a lower quality) to comply with minimum regulatory ratios. For instance, institutions may meet the 6% Tier 1 requirement by using exclusively CET1 instruments. The same holds true for the 8% Total Capital Ratio, where an institution may issue exclusively CET1 items and instruments or CET1 and AT1 instruments. Tier 2 instruments may not be used as a substitute for AT1 or CET1 instruments.

input: Answer this question about Bahrain: 5.13 Are external auditors subject to independent oversight by …     d. Other (please explain)
target:
The external auditors are not subject to independent oversight by the Ministry of Finance, or the Central Banks Banking Supervision Directorates.
The banks just need to follow the requirements within the CBB law that have to be met with respect to:
- the appointment of external auditors,
- seeking the CBB's approval for the appointment or re-appointment,
- auditors independence,
- And auditor restrictions.
Audit firms have to be compliant with applicable laws and regulations (including legislative Decree No. 26 of 1996 â€œwith respect to auditorsâ€; the Ministry of Industry and Commerce's Ministerial Resolution No. 6 of 1998; and relevant Bahrain Stock Exchange regulations). The Ministry of Commerce can be considered an entity overseeing
the auditors in that the MOC may request based on Decree No. 26 the auditors to provide reports â€œby documents about joint stock companies or which they audit their accountâ€ and â€¦ â€œmay make the comments it deems appropriate concerning such reports.â€

input: Answer this question about Australia: 8.24 Have you introduced changes to your deposit protection system as a result of the 2007-2009 global financial crisis?     e. Other (please explain)
target:
The Australian Government deposit guarantee was introduced in October 2008. The initial guarantee amount was set at AUD $1,000,000 which was later revised to AUD $250,000 per account holder per institution in October 2011. _x000D_
APRA introduced Prudential Standard APS 910 Financial Claims Scheme in July 2013 which sets out the minimum requirements that a locally incorporated ADI must meet to ensure that it is adequately prepared, should it become a declared ADI for FCS purposes. _x000D_
In addition, APRA is continuing to strengthen the FCS assurance framework to build on ADIsâ€™ ability to meet APRAâ€™s requirements regarding FCS data, systems and processes. This includes the release of a testing schedule, communication scripts and a revised assurance report template for external auditors as well as a program of FCS focused onsite reviews conducted by APRA.

Republic Act No. 9576, which amended the PDIC Charter, took effect in June 2009. The said Law increased the maximum deposit insurance coverage from P250,000 to P500,000. _x000D_
In 2016, the PDIC Charter was further amended with the passage of Republic Act No. 10846. The said Law has provided PDIC with enhanced authorities to allow depositors quicker access to their insured deposits in the event of bank closure; hastened the liquidation process for closed banks, and imposed stiffer sanctions and penalties on bank owners, officers and employees who commit fraud, irregularities and anomalies.

input: Answer this question about Romania: 8.24 Have you introduced changes to your deposit protection system as a result of the 2007-2009 global financial crisis? 8.24.1 Please specify the year when these changes were introduced or the time period they were in place if they have subsequently been withdrawn.
target:
Expansion of coverage (types of exposures, nature of depositors etc.): Starting with 30 June 2009, the list of deposits excluded from any repayment was supplemented with deposits of economic entities that did not fall into the category of micro, small and medium enterprises according to their size._x000D_
After the entry into force of the national legislation transposing Directive 2014/49/EU on deposit guarantee schemes (recast), the list of covered depositors has been extended by adding deposits held by corporates (other than micro, small and medium-sized enterprises) and those of the persons designated as directors, members of the supervisory board, auditors, significant shareholders of the concerned credit institution, and those of the persons having such capacity in other companies within the credit institution group, the members of the families of the above-mentioned individuals, as well as the third persons acting on their behalf (extensions currently in force)._x000D_
Increase in amount covered: Following the transposition into the national legislation of Directive 2009/14/EC, the amount covered increased from the RON equivalent of EUR 20,000 (applicable from 1st of January 2007) to the RON equivalent of EUR 100,000 (applicable from 30th of December 2010):_x000D_
-	between 1 January 2006 â€“ 31 December 2006: the RON equivalent of EUR 15.000; _x000D_
-	between 1 January 2007- 15 October 2008: the RON equivalent of EUR 20.000; _x000D_
-	between 15 October 2008 â€“ 30 December 2010: the RON equivalent of EUR 50.000; _x000D_
-	since 2011 - the RON equivalent of EUR 100.000 (currently in force)._x000D_
Moreover, following the transposition into the national legislation of Directive 2014/49/EU, certain eligible deposits such as deposits resulting from real estate transactions relating to private residential properties, those linked to life events such as retirement, dismissal, invalidity or death or those based on the payment of insurance benefits or compensation for criminal injuries or wrongful conviction are protected above â‚¬ 100,000 (maximum â‚¬ 200,000) for a limited period of time, no longer than 12 months after the amount has been credited in an account held at the concerned credit institution or from the moment when such deposits become legally transferable to another credit institution._x000D_
Other:_x000D_
-	shortening the repayment period of covered depositors: 2015 â€“ currently in force (following the transposition into the national legislation of Directive 2014/49/EU, deposit guarantee schemes are required to make available the repayable amounts to covered depositors within 7 working days from the date on which the deposits became unavailable);_x000D_
The repayment deadlines have been gradually cut, as follows:_x000D_
-	1 July 2004 - 30 June 2009: the repayment should have started no later than 2 months from the date of receipt from the Deposits Guarantee Fund in the Banking System liquidator of the list that contained the natural and legal persons having covered deposits, the total amount of covered deposits of each depositor and its obligations to the credit institution, but no later than 3 months after the deposits have become unavailable. In exceptional circumstances and in special cases, the Deposits Guarantee Fund in the Banking System could request to the National Bank of Romania to extend the repayment term. No such extension could have exceeded 3 months (the National Bank of Romania could not have granted more than two extensions, at the request of the deposit guarantee scheme)._x000D_
-	30 June 2009 â€“ 31 December 2010: the repayment should have started no later than 3 months from the date on which the deposits have become unavailable. _x000D_
-	1 January 2011 â€“ 14 December 2015: the repayment should have started no later than 20 working days after the deposits have become unavailable. By way of exception, the National Bank of Romania could have approved, at the Deposits Guarantee Fund in the Banking Systemâ€™s request, in absolutely exceptional circumstances, the extension with no more than 10 working days of the period for making available the repayable amounts to covered depositors._x000D_
-	since 14 December 2015, deposit guarantee schemes are required to make available the repayable amounts to covered depositors within 7 working days from the date on which the deposits become unavailable._x000D_
-	introduction of risk based contributions: 2015 â€“ currently in force;_x000D_
-	regulating a mechanism of mutual borrowing between officially recognized scheme from European Union: 2015 â€“ currently in force (following the transposition into the national legislation of Directive 2014/49/EU);_x000D_
-	regulating the amount of available financial means which the deposit guarantee scheme is required to reach (the target level): From 28 March 2006 to 14 December 2015, in order to establish the optimal financial means necessary, the target level of the deposit guarantee scheme resources was determined as a ratio between the necessary financial means and the total amount of covered deposits, and was approved by the National Bank of Romania. Since 14 December 2015, the available financial means of a deposit guarantee scheme shall at least reach a target level of 0,8% of the amount of the covered deposits of its members;_x000D_
-	appointing a designated authority for the supervision of the deposit guarantee schemes: 2015 â€“ currently in force (following the transposition into the national legislation of Directive 2014/49/EU);_x000D_
-	imposing the obligation to perform stress tests on the deposit guarantee schemeâ€™s own systems: 2015 â€“ currently in force (following the transposition into the national legislation of Directive 2014/49/EU);_x000D_
-	improving the standard of information given to depositors on the protection of their deposits: _x000D_
Since 14 December 2015, following the transposition into the national legislation of Directive 2014/49/EU, it was established the obligation of credit institutions to inform existing or potential depositors regarding the coverage and the deposit guarantee scheme, through the account statements and the Depositor Information Template (currently in force).

input: Answer this question about Thailand: 8.24 Have you introduced changes to your deposit protection system as a result of the 2007-2009 global financial crisis? 8.24.1 Please specify the year when these changes were introduced or the time period they were in place if they have subsequently been withdrawn.
target:
Due to the Global Financial Crisis in 2008, the Cabinet extended the coverage limit on 28 October, 2008 to cover all deposits in the first three years. As such, the levels were adjusted as follows:

Date /	 Original Coverage Level /	Revised Coverage after GFC
Aug 11, 2008 - Aug 10, 2009 /	Blanket guarantee / 	 Blanket guarantee
Aug 11, 2009 - Aug 10, 2010 /	100 million baht /	 Blanket guarantee
Aug 11, 2010 - Aug 10, 2011 /	 50 million baht /	 Blanket guarantee
Aug 11, 2011 - Aug 10, 2012 /	 10 million baht /	 50 million baht
Aug 11, 2012 onwards /	 1 million baht / 	 1 million baht

Then, with the Euro Crisis in 2011, the Cabinet extended the coverage levels again to promote confidence in the Thai financial institution system according to this table:

Date /	 Coverage Level
Aug 11, 2010 - Aug 10, 2011 /	 Blanket guarantee
Aug 11, 2011 - Aug 10, 2015 /	 50 million baht
Aug 11, 2015 - Aug 10, 2016 / 25 million baht
Aug 11, 2016 onwards /	 1 million baht

In April 2016, the Cabinet extended coverage levels one more time due to changing economic conditions as well as to increase the amount of time that depositors have to make adjustments as shown below:

Date /	 Coverage Level
Aug 11, 2015 - Aug 10, 2016 / 25 million baht
Aug 11, 2016 - Aug 10, 2018 / 15 million baht
Aug 11, 2018 - Aug 10, 2019 / 10 million baht
Aug 11, 2019 - Aug 10, 2020 / 5 million baht
Aug 11, 2020 onwards / 	 1 million baht

target: 1)	An asset, including a leased asset, becomes non-Â¬ performing when it ceases to generate income for the bank. Banks are required to classify non-performing assets further into the following three categories based on the period for which the asset has remained non-Â¬ performing and the realisability of the dues: I. SubÂ¬standard Assets: A subÂ¬standard asset would be one, which has remained NPA for a period less than or equal to 12 months. Such an asset will have well defined credit weaknesses that jeopardise the liquidation of the debt and are characterised by the distinct possibility that the banks will sustain some loss, if deficiencies are not corrected. II. Doubtful Assets: An asset would be classified as doubtful if it has remained in the subÂ¬standard category for a period of 12 months. A loan classified as doubtful has all the weaknesses inherent in assets that were classified as sub-standard, with the added characteristic that the weaknesses make collection or liquidation in full, â€“ on the basis of currently known facts, conditions and values â€“ highly questionable and improbable. III. Loss Assets: A loss asset is one where loss has been identified by the bank or internal or external auditors or the RBI inspection but the amount has not been written off wholly. In other words, such an asset is considered uncollectible and of such little value that its continuance as a bankable asset is not warranted although there may be some salvage or recovery value.

target: Advances classified as a loss are considered uncollectable and of such little value that their continuation as recoverable advances is not warranted. This classification does not mean that the advance has absolutely no recovery value, but rather it is not practical or desirable to defer writing off this basically worthless advance even though partial recovery may be effected in the future. Advances classified as a loss include bankrupt companies and loans to insolvent firms with negative working capital and cash flow. Banks should not retain advances on the books while attempting long-term recoveries. Losses should be taken in the period in which they surface as uncollectable. Non-performing loans and receivables which are 360 days or more overdue are also classified as a loss.

input: Answer this question about Kyrgyz Republic: 9.11.1 What are general provisions based on?     c. Other (please explain)
target:
According to Regulation on Assets Classification and Relevant Deductions to Potential Losses Reserve, for the purpose of assets classification, Banks shall monitor and analyze data on funds movement and estimate clientâ€™s ability to receive sufficient amount of money to settle the asset. Under the contract for assets, the bank is entitled to receive the information about the clientâ€™s financial solvency (information on movement of funds) on a regular basis, in addition to the mandatory quarterly reports (balance sheets and profit and loss statements)._x000D_
The absence of reliable financial information (for instance, clientâ€™s balance sheets and profit and loss statements not audited by external audit) and its proper analysis is a serious shortcoming. As provided by the laws of the Kyrgyz Republic, a client shall bear responsibility for completeness and reliability of reports and information submitted to the bank. However, assuming risks associated with provision of assets, the bank should check authenticity of these reports both prior to providing the asset, and subsequently, until complete repayment to the bank._x000D_
 The National Bank of the Kyrgyz Republic sets the following contributions to the Potential Losses Reserves:_x000D_
1. General Reserves:	_x000D_
- Normal - 0%;_x000D_
- Satisfactory - 1/2/2,5%;_x000D_
- Assets under supervision - 5/10/15%;_x000D_
2. Specific Reserves:_x000D_
- Substandard - 15%/25%;_x000D_
- Doubtful - 50%;_x000D_
- Losses - 100%.

input: Answer this question about Panama: 9.11.1 What are general provisions based on?     c. Other (please explain)
target:
Rule 4 – 2013, ARTICLE 37. AMOUNT OF THE DYNAMIC RESERVES. The amount of the dynamic reserves is obtained by calculating the following components: 
1. Component #1: The amount obtained by multiplying the balance of risk weighted assets for loans classified under the normal category by the Alpha coefficient from the chart.
2. Component #2: The amount obtained by multiplying the quarterly variation in risk-weighted assets for loans classified under the normal category, if positive, by the Beta coefficient from the chart. If the variation is negative, the amount is zero. 
3. Component #3: The amount of the variation in the balance of specific reserves during the quarter. 
The amount of dynamic reserves that must be maintained at the end of the quarter is the sum of the two components obtained in numbers 1 and 2 above minus the third component, taking its mathematical sign into account, i.e. if the third component is negative, it must be added.
Chart for the Calculation of Dynamic Reserves
Alpha	Beta
1.50%	5.00%

The following restrictions apply to the amount of the dynamic reserve: 
a. It cannot be greater than 2.5% of the risk-weighted assets of the loans classified under the normal category.
b. It cannot be less than 1.25% of the risk-weighted assets on the loans classified under the normal category. 
c. It cannot be less than the amount established in the previous quarter, unless the decrease is the result of a conversion to specific provisions. The Superintendency of Banks will establish the criteria for the above conversion.
The reserve called “global minimum” will be considered part of the dynamic reserve for the purpose of meeting the required reserve on the date in which the dynamic reserves are calculated.

input: Answer this question about Bulgaria: 11.4.1 What triggers/thresholds are used for initiating automatic actions?     e. Other (please specify)
target:
On the grounds of Art. 44, para. 1 of the Law on the Recovery and Resolution of Credit Institutions and Investment Firms, the BNB may apply early intervention measures, where based on an assessment it determines that the institution
does or could infringe in the near future the requirements of Regulation (EU) No. 575/2013, the Law on Credit Institutions or their implementing acts due to the rapidly deteriorating financial condition of the institution, including as a result of the threatened liquidity, a rapidly increasing level of leverage, of non-performing loans or of credit concentrations. The assessment shall be based on a set of indicators established by an ordinance of the relevant competent authority, which may include an indicator taking into
account the availability of own funds exceeding the minimum requirement to the institution with no less than 1.5 percentage points.

input: Answer this question about Lebanon: 11.4.1 What triggers/thresholds are used for initiating automatic actions?         No - Explanation
target: Such companies are not subject to a special resolution regime per se but are to a certain extent subject to Bank of Lebanon (BDL) regulation. In this regard, holding companies owning more that 5% of the capital of a bank should abide by certain regulations issued by the BDL relating to shareholders, the nature of the shares and transfers of the latter . Moreover, these companies must provide the BDL and the BCC with all the requested information related to the companyâ€™s balance sheet and members who own whether directly or indirectly five percent (5%) or more of the total shares of any Lebanese bank or ten percent (10%) or more of the total shares of any Lebanese financial institution, in which the company is a shareholder, including the beneficial owners. Finally, any amendment of these companies bylaws shall require the approval of the BDL.

input: Answer this question about Russian Federation: 11.17 Have you introduced significant changes to the bank resolution framework in your country as a result of the 2007-2009 global financial crisis?     c. Other (please explain)
target:
1. The Federal Law No. 175-FZ of October 27, 2008 on Additional Measures for Enhancing the Stability of the Banking System in the Period Until December 31, 2014 stipulates that for the purpose of supporting the stability of the banking system and protecting the lawful interests of banks' depositors and creditors if there are signs of the unstable financial state of banks or situations are discovered that threaten the stability of the banking system and the lawful interests of banks' depositors and creditors the Central Bank of the Russian Federation (CBR) and the state corporation "Deposit Insurance Agency" (DIA) are entitled to take measures for preventing the bankruptcy of the banks participating in the system of compulsory insurance of natural persons' deposits in the banks of the Russian Federation.
2.1. The Federal Law No. 432-FZ of December 22, 2014 on Amending Certain Legislative Acts of the Russian Federation and Declaring Invalidated Certain Legislative Acts (Provisions of Legislative Acts) of the Russian Federation has updated the banking legislation (including the Bankruptcy Law No. 127-FZ), to introduce a more comprehensive legal framework with regard to resolving failing banks, including both measures to prevent insolvencies (bankruptcies) of credit institutions and procedures for declaring credit institutions insolvent (bankrupt) and subsequently liquidating them â€“ with the participation of the DIA.
The 2014 law enables the bailing-in of subordinated creditors through write-off or conversion of their debt into bank shares.
2.2. The Federal Law No. 84-FZ of May 1, 2017 on Amending Certain Legislative Acts of the Russian Federation:
- provides that financial resources of the fund created by the CBR are exercised to provide direct capital injections into problematic banks instead of DIAâ€™s resolution mechanisms and CBRâ€™s loans. A stake in the bank acquired for account of the fund will be sold to third-party investor in a public auction upon successful completion of a bankâ€™s financial rehabilitation. The new framework enables the central bank to assume control over DIAâ€™s bank resolution activities by taking over a majority of seats on DIAâ€™s Board of Directors (the Russian government holds the majority at present).
- stipulates a new condition of CBRâ€™s financial aid. It implies termination of obligations to the top management of the bank, as well as to bank controlling persons, possessing 20% or more of stakes for the last 3 years.

input: Answer this question about Ireland: 12.1.1 Please specify the name of the body/agency (or multiple agencies if this is the case) that supervises for prudential purposes …     a. Commercial banks
target:
The breakdown between authorities is not based on the type of bank that is supervised. Rather, it is based on a set of criteria which capture:
- the absolute size of the bank (above EUR 30 bn of total assets, an institution is supervised by the European Central bank),
- its importance for the economy of the European Union or any participating Member State (if the ratio of the total assets over GDP of the participating Member State of establishment exceeds 20% and unless the total value of its assets is below EUR 5 bn, an institution is supervised by the European Central bank), 
Following a notification by its national competent authority that it considers such an institution of significant relevance with regard to the domestic economy, and if the European Central Bank takes a decision to confirm such significance following a comprehensive assessment of the balance sheet of this institution by the European Central Bank, an institution would also be supervised by the European Central Bank.
The European Central Bank may also, on its own initiative, consider an institution to be of significant relevance where it has established banking subsidiaries in more than one participating Member States and its cross-border assets or liabilities represent more than 20% of its total assets or liabilities and the total value of its assets exceeds EUR 5 bn.
In addition, the three most significant credit institutions in each participating Member State, unless justified by particular circumstances, are supervised by the European Central bank. 
All other credit institutions are supervised by the national competent authority of that participating Member State.

ARTICLE 17. REMOVAL. The directors and the Superintendent can only be removed from their positions by the causes established in this Decree Law, pursuant to the decision of the Third Hall of the Supreme Court of Justice and pursuant to the process stipulated by the Judicial Code. The Executive Branch and the Board of Directors are legitimized to request their removal._x000D_
_x000D_
ARTICLE 18. CAUSES FOR REMOVAL. The Third Hall of the Supreme Court of Justice can order the removal of a member of the Board of Directors or of the Superintendent that incurs in any of the following causes:_x000D_
_x000D_
1.	Permanent inability to fulfill his/her functions._x000D_
_x000D_

_x000D_

input: Answer this question about Germany: 12.22 For material foreign operations (whether in the form of branches or subsidiaries), do you ...     d. Other (please specify)
target: In order to ensure a consistent and effective supervision of both national and foreign activities of LSIs, colleges of supervisors can be established. While the establishment of colleges for EEA banks with subsidiaries or significant branches in other EEA countries that are not participating in the SSM are governed by EU law including EBA guidelines, college activities concerning banks with material foreign operations in non-EEA countries are based on bilateral MOUs between NCAs. For example, third country-MOUs have been concluded between GER and USA and GER and JPN. Currently, there are five LSI EBA Supervisory Colleges where GER acts as home supervisor and four colleges where GER is involved as host supervisor. Cooperation within the framework of EBA colleges enables member supervisory authorities to exchange information, coordinate supervisory activities and to reach joint decisions on the risk-based capital adequacy of cross-border groups and their EEA subsidiaries.

input: Answer this question about Germany: 12.24.1 Because you do not have an integrated financial supervisory agency covering all significant financial institutions, how is a financial group with significant banking activities supervised (choose the most appropriate option)?         Explanation
target: A financial group with significant banking activities is supervised on a consolidated basis by BaFin/Bundesbank or the ECB-SSM as a group according to CRR and the SSM regulation. In some cases, groups are additionally identified as financial conglomerates, which can also be bank-led. In those cases, a coordinator is determined, cp. with Article 10 FiCoD (Directive 2002/87/EC). In Germany, it can be the BaFin or the ECB-SSM. A financial conglomerate is then additionally supervised according to the FiCoD-rules, which have been transposed to German law by the Finanzkonglomerateaufsichtsgesetz (FKAG).

Answer this question about Brazil: 14.1 What body/agency has the responsibility to implement, oversee and/or enforce any aspect of financial consumer protection laws and regulations that apply to banks?     d. Other (please explain)
target: The National Consumer Defense System (Sistema Nacional de Defesa do Consumidor - â€œSNDCâ€), which is coordinated by the National Consumer Protection Secretariat (Secretaria Nacional do Consumidor - â€œSenaconâ€) of the Ministry of Justice, is responsible for enforcing the general consumer protection regime in this jurisdiction, which is set by Law nÂº 8,078/1990, whose provisions must be observed by any service provider, including financial institutions while rendering financial services. The Central Bank of Brazil (BCB) does not take part in the SNDC. Nevertheless, it must be noted that, in order to ensure the soundness and efficiency of Brazilâ€™s financial system, the BCB and the National Monetary Council have approved in the past few years several provisions in order to promote fair and responsible conduct of business by financial institutions when dealing with financial consumersâ€™ affairs. Taking this supervisory model into account, there is a bilateral agreement in place between the BCB and Senacon in order to conduct joint-actions to tackle the most frequent issues faced by financial consumers in this jurisdiction.

input: Answer this question about South Africa: 14.1 What body/agency has the responsibility to implement, oversee and/or enforce any aspect of financial consumer protection laws and regulations that apply to banks?     d. Other (please explain)
target:
There is currently no single agency responsible for consumer protection in respect of banking conduct, but that it is currently split between three different agencies, viz: (i) The Consumer Commission, our general consumer protection agency; (ii) The National Credit Regulator, in relation to credit extension to consumers; and (iii) the FSB through the FAIS Act, in relation to advice and intermediary services on bank products. Banks are also subject to the consumer protection requirements of the Financial Advisory and Intermediary Services Act, in so far as it provides financial advisory and intermediary services.On 1 April 2011, Consumer Protection Act, 68 of 2009, (The CPA) came into effect. The object of the act is among others, to promote a fair, accessible and sustainable marketplace for consumer products and services and for that purpose to establish national norms and standards relating to consumer protection, to provide for improved standards of consumer information, to prohibit certain unfair marketing and business practices, to promote responsible consumer behaviour, to promote a consistent legislative and enforcement framework relating to consumer transactions and agreements, to establish the National Consumer Commission. The CPAâ€™s definition of â€œserviceâ€ includes, but is not limited to-_x000D_
any banking services, or related or similar financial services, or the undertaking, underwriting or assumption of any risk by one person on behalf of another, except to the extent that any such service-_x000D_
constitutes advice or intermediary services that is subject to regulation in terms of the Financial Advisory and Intermediary Services Act, 2002 (Act No. 37 of 2002) (FAIS Act) ; or is regulated in terms of the Long-term Insurance Act, 1998 (Act No. 52 of 1998), or the Short-term Insurance Act, 1998 (Act No. 53 of 1998). The FAIS Act and the Insurance Acts are supervised by the Financial Services Board. _x000D_
_x000D_
The National Credit Regulator (NCR) was established as the regulator under the National Credit Act No. 34 of 2005 (The NCA) and is responsible for the regulation of the South African credit industry. It is tasked with carrying out education, research, policy development, registration of industry participants, investigation of complaints, and ensuring the enforcement of the Act. The National Consumer Tribunal is an independent adjudicative entity, deriving its mandate from the National Credit Act (NCA). The Tribunal has powers to, inter alia, impose administrative fines, require repayment of excess charges etc. _x000D_
_x000D_
The Banking Association of South Africa developed the Banking Code to which all members (banks) must adhere. The Code is a voluntary code that sets out the minimum standards for service and conduct a financial customer can expect from a bank with regard to the services and products it offers. _x000D_
_x000D_
BAnks that are members of the Banking Association are also subject to the jurisdiction of the Ombudman for Banking Services (OBS) . Any bank customer may lodge a complaint against his or her bank with the OBS, provided the OBS has jurisdiction._x000D_
_x000D_
The FAIS Ombud deals with consumer complaints against Financial Servicve Providers (including banks) and provides an efficient and affordable dispute resolution mechanism. The Office of the Ombud for Financial Services Providers became mandated on_x000D_
30 September 2004 to accepting and dealing with complaints. The Ombudâ€™s determinations are binding and may include payment of monetary awards, damages and costs with interest._x000D_
_x000D_
In terms of the proposed Twin Peak model of financial regulation. The Financial Sector Conduct Authority will be responsible for, inter alia, the protection of financial customers by promoting fair treatment of financial customers by financial institutions (including banks) and providing financial customers with financial education programmes and otherwise promoting financial literacy and the ability of financial customers and potential financial customers to make sound financial decisions._x000D_

input: Answer this question about Denmark: 14.5.3 By law or regulation, which of the following are part of the disclosure requirements mentioned in 14.5 that banks need to comply with upon signing a credit contract (mark all options that apply):         Explanation
target: As a member of the EU Denmark is obliged to transpose the EU regulation requiring periodic statements for payment accounts into Danish law. input: Answer this question about Germany: 14.5.3 By law or regulation, which of the following are part of the disclosure requirements mentioned in 14.5 that banks need to comply with upon signing a credit contract (mark all options that apply):         Explanation
target: According to para 248 Â§8 Introductory Act to the Civil Code the payment service provider has to inform the payer immediately after the amount has been charged to the account. Deviating from the aforementioned requirement, according to para 248 Â§10 Introductory Act to the Civil Code, the periodic statement can be provided at least monthly if agreed by the payment service provider and the payment service user.

input: Answer this question about Malawi: 14.5.3 By law or regulation, which of the following are part of the disclosure requirements mentioned in 14.5 that banks need to comply with upon signing a credit contract (mark all options that apply):         Explanation
target: BI ANNUALLY

input: Answer this question about Mauritius: 14.5.3 By law or regulation, which of the following are part of the disclosure requirements mentioned in 14.5 that banks need to comply with upon signing a credit contract (mark all options that apply):         Explanation
target: As per Section 57(5A) of the banking Act 2004, statements have to be sent on a regular basis but at least once every year. For credit agreements, as per Section 37(6)(b)of the Banking Act 2004, statements have to be sent every 6 months.

input: Answer this question about Mexico: 14.5.3 By law or regulation, which of the following are part of the disclosure requirements mentioned in 14.5 that banks need to comply with upon signing a credit contract (mark all options that apply):         Explanation
target: The financial statements must issue free of charge and sent to the address indicated by the users, monthly or with the agreed periodicity, which can not be more than 6 months, within 10 days after the corresponding cutoff date, without any fail to generate statements of account. In substitution of the aforementioned obligation, the Financial Institution may agree with the User to consult the account statement through any means, including electronic means.

input: Answer this question about Oman: 14.5.3 By law or regulation, which of the following are part of the disclosure requirements mentioned in 14.5 that banks need to comply with upon signing a credit contract (mark all options that apply):         Explanation
target: half yearly

input: Answer this question about Slovak Republic: 14.5.3 By law or regulation, which of the following are part of the disclosure requirements mentioned in 14.5 that banks need to comply with upon signing a credit contract (mark all options that apply):         Explanation
target: Monthly, quarterly, annually and upon request in the form of an amortization chart - consumer credits_x000D_

input: Answer this question about South Africa: 14.5.3 By law or regulation, which of the following are part of the disclosure requirements mentioned in 14.5 that banks need to comply with upon signing a credit contract (mark all options that apply):         Explanation
target: The frequency of the statements will vary by the type of account, e.g. you will receive a statement for your mortgage at least every 6 months; every month for your overdraft and credit card facility and every two months for any other credit agreement, unless otherwise agreed or unless there have not been any transactions. You will need to check with your bank as to whether it is possible to have account statements provided more frequently than normally available on your type of account. FAIS requires quarterly or annual statements. Requests for statements for a specific period may attract a charge.
